On Thu, 2003-09-18 at 23:29, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Malcolm Sparks wrote:
> 
> > Good stuff. I accept all the good points made about using assertions in
> > unit tests. But the point I was making about logging was echoing this
> > sentiment:
> > 
> > "Logging equips the developer with detailed context for application
> > failures. On the other hand, testing provides quality assurance and
> > confidence in the application. Logging and testing should not be
> > confused. They are complementary. When logging is wisely used, it can
> > prove to be an essential tool."
> > http://jakarta.apache.org/log4j/docs/index.html
> 
> Yep. The problem is when one uses logging as a substitute for testing, 
> which is still very, very common.
> 
> In my opinion, one logs to help provide the context for complex 
> troubleshooting. For anything simpler, one tests.
> 
> Reasonable?

Yes :)
